channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Face masks compulsory in hospitals from 15 June
item.description: Medical and other staff will have to wear surgical masks at all times, while outpatients and visitors will not be allowed in without wearing the sort of face coverings that can be made at home.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Police link suspect to missing schoolboy, 6
item.description: BREAKING: German detectives investigating Christian Brueckner , 43, have contacted the family of René Hasee to say they were looking into his 1996 abduction again.

item.title: Trump retweets interview where Candace Owens says she is 'sickened' that George Floyd is a martyr
item.description: Owens made the controversial remarks during an interview with radio host Glenn Beck Friday. Trump shared a portion of the interview with his 81.8 million followers.

item.title: America's top soldier General Milley, had shouting match with Donald Trump forced him to back down
item.description: The President and the military's most senior official General Mark Milley are said to have got into a row in the Oval Office over Trump's demand for troops on the streets to calm protests in US cities.

item.title: Buffalo Mayor says 75-year-old man who was shoved to the ground by police was an 'agitator'
item.description: Buffalo Mayor Byron Brown said the 75-year-old man who was shoved to the ground by two cops on Thursday was an 'agitator' and had been asked to leave the area 'numerous' times.

item.title: Matt Hancock warns protesters against going to George Floyd demonstrations amid Covid-19 pandemic
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock last night warned Britons not to attend large scale anti-racism demonstrations this weekend due to the risk of coronavirus, which he said remained a 'real threat'.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Boris Johnson's Great Recovery Bill for economy
item.description: Downing Street is asking Ministers to submit ideas for reforms that would allow firms to adapt to the pandemic upheaval and be included in the Prime Minister's 'Great Recovery Bill'.

item.title: Can America's most divisive President survive November's election? Reporter says he's set to win
item.description: DAVID KAY JOHNSTON: After the anarchic scenes of recent days, many will conclude that the American people will kick Donald Trump out of the White House in November's election.

item.title: Celebrity Gogglebox fans call out the show for seemingly 'breaking social distancing rules'
item.description: Celebrity Gogglebox viewers were left furious on Friday as the stars seemingly 'broke social distancing rules' as they mingled with others from different households.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Does evidence show virus IS getting weaker?
item.description: An average of 114,000 people were diagnosed with coronavirus worldwide in the last seven days, up from 86,000 per day at the start of May - but deaths in the same time frame fell from 5,100 to 4,300.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Villa where Christian Brueckner raped tourist
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Christian Brueckner broke into the secluded home two years before the three-year-old went missing from her family's apartment in the resort of Praia da Luz.

item.title: Boris Johnson offers to accept EU tariffs to win trade deal to break deadlock with Brussels
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson's chief negotiator David Frost has offered to accept tariffs on a small number of goods to break the deadlock with Brussels in a significant new offer to the European Union.

item.title: Billionaire prince Albert of Monaco reveals all about life in a tax haven
item.description: Albert gets to decide which applicants will be allowed the privilege of becoming a citizen. Only around 9,000 of the population are citizens - known as Monegasques - the rest are residents.

item.title: Madeleine McCann witness says Christian Brueckner IS the man she saw near apartment
item.description: A nanny who looked after Maddie in the holiday resort before she disappeared recognised a photo of Christian Brueckner when she was shown it by Portuguese police.

item.title: 5,500 Facebook employees complained about decision to keep up Trump's 'looting and shooting' posts
item.description: Facebook employees are angry with CEO Mark Zuckerberg (pictured), according to documents. This week, Timothy Aveni, Owen Anderson, and a third employee resigned in protest.

item.title: Protesters around the world clash with police as they demand justice for George Floyd
item.description: For more than a week people have rallied outside US embassies to demand justice for George Floyd - the man who gasped 'I can't breathe' when a white police officer knelt on his neck in Minneapolis.

item.title: Scientists find snake eels which had burst out of fish's stomach cavity after being eaten alive
item.description: Scientists found when snake eels are swallowed whole by fish, the eels use its tails to puncture the stomach and escape, but the creatures become trapped in the rib cage, die and slowly mummify.

item.title: Father is sent a £50MILLION car insurance bill
item.description: Mohammad Irfan, 38, from Ilford, London, was told the insurance payments on his Ford Kuga were £4.2million per month.

item.title: Al-Qaeda chief in North Africa killed by French forces in military operation in Mali
item.description: French defence minister Florence Parly has announced that Abdelmalek Droukdel was killed on Wednesday during a military operation in the African country of Mali.

item.title: ANDREW PIERCE looks at the BBC's new director-general Tim Davie
item.description: ANDREW PIERCE: When Slovenia recently became the 50th country to make its own Strictly Come Dancing under BBC licence, there was a broad smile on Tim Davie's face as he sat in his office.

item.title: How Number 10's Covid weekend briefings lost 25 million viewers
item.description: On average more than three million people a day have tuned into the daily Number 10 Covid-19 press briefing since the first scheduled conference on March 16, before the lockdown.

item.title: Troops storm beaches, scale cliffs and swoop over occupied France in stunning unseen photos
item.description: Photos colourised by an Artificial Intelligence algorithm show British and US troops storming the beaches and talking to members of the French Resistance after the D-Day landings in Normandy.

item.title: WHO finally says EVERYONE should wear a mask if you can't keep your distance
item.description: The World Health Organization said Friday it is now advising that masks be worn beyond health care settings in areas where the virus is spreading if a social distance can't be kept.
item.media:description: FILE - In this Friday, March 20, 2020 file photo, passengers wearing face masks travel on a Piccadilly Line underground train in London. The World Health Organization on Friday June 5, 2020, broadened its recommendations for the use of masks during the coronavirus pandemic and is now advising that in areas where the virus is spreading, people should wear fabric masks when social distancing is not possible, such as on public transport and in shops. (AP Photo/Matt Dunham, File)

item.title: Searches on Twitter for the term 'racist' surface President Donald Trump's name as the top result
item.description: According to a report from CNET, Twitter says the linkage between 'racist' and Trump's account were a product of its algorithm which ties accounts to common terms associated with them.

item.title: MP Bob Seely apologises after going to a barbecue during lockdown
item.description: Bob Seely apologised for attending the barbecue along with his girlfriend on the Isle of Wight which was hosted by the Spectator's deputy editor Freddy Gray.

item.title: BBC faces sexism row after appointing a 17th consecutive man as director-general
item.description: The BBC's ex-China editor Carrie Gracie says Tim Davie is white, male and 'not diverse'. She was joined by veteran broadcaster Joan Bakewell in calling for a woman to take the role.

item.title: Naga Munchetty says broadcasters are not 'robots or idiots'
item.description: The BBC Breakfast presenter said her role is not to sit and 'blankly' read the news but instead inform viewers 'neutrally' and give insight where possible.

item.title: Reddit's Alexis Ohanian RESIGNS to help 'curb racial hate'
item.description: Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian made the shock announcement in a video uploaded to his Instagram page Friday midday.

item.title: Emotional moment husband, 87, and wife, 91, forced to live in separate care homes are reunited
item.description: Retired police officer Peter Foster, 87, and his wife of 59 years Doreen, 91, were forced apart when Peter fell unwell and had to be hospitalised in February. The Sunderland pair have now been reunited.

item.title: Kate Garraway says husband Derek Draper may be locked in a coma 'forever'
item.description: The Good Morning Britain presenter, 53, has revealed her husband Derek Draper may be trapped in a coma forever, with doctors warning her to prepare for the 'second worst case scenario.'

item.title: Penny Lancaster: 'I've hit the menopause in lockdown - but at least Rod's doing the dishes!'
item.description: In a conversation lurching from policing, to Rod's cancer to trying to get all members of the Stewart clan on a Zoom call at once, Penny Lancaster reveals how she hit the menopause in lockdown.

item.title: PLATELL'S PEOPLE: Day by day, the fresh torment for the poor McCanns must be unbearable
item.description: PLATELL'S PEOPLE: Kate McCann and Gerry appear closer than ever to discovering the truth. And they are having to confront the belief of German prosecutors that their little girl really is dead.

item.title: Two Buffalo police officers are under criminal investigation after shoving man, 75, to the ground
item.description: The two officers are under criminal investigation after footage captured them shoving Martin Gugino and leaving him with critical injuries in an incident in front of Buffalo's City Hall on Thursday night.

item.title: Woman saves hundreds of unwanted plants
item.description: Green-fingered Sarah Gerrard-Jones, from Hertfordshire, devotes her days to bringing withering blooms back to life - and has already saved hundreds from being chucked in the bin.

item.title: Kate and Gerry McCann's close adviser Clarence Mitchell believes the latest development could be key
item.description: For Kate and Gerry McCann there have been many heart-stopping moments since their daughter Madeleine went missing from their holiday apartment in Portugal 13 years ago.

item.title: Two fair-haired little girls who vanished on a family trip...
item.description: Just like Madeleine, Inga Gehricke's beautiful smile lights up her family snaps. The German girl is slightly older, with her hair growing long and worn in plaits.

item.title: From free-range to organic and now 'room to roam', how 12 supermarket roasts compare
item.description: You can pick up a whole chicken for as little as £2.40 at some supermarkets. Many worry that such cheap prices mean the bird has had an unhappy life.

item.title: Couple who spent £600,000 arguing for two years over divorce left with £5,000 each after legal costs
item.description: The middle-aged pair, who live in London, split after 22 years of marriage and three children and have since spent two years trying to gouge a larger slice of marital assets from each other (file image).

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect Christian Brueckner was tried for sex attacks on young children at age 17
item.description: Christian Brueckner was 17 when he molested a six-year-old girl in a public playground in his home town of Wuerzburg, Bavaria. He only stopped when the schoolgirl began to scream.

item.title: No.10 PPE tsar Lord Deighton thanks Mail Force charity for helping supply Britain with hospital kit
item.description: Downing Street's Lord Deighton (pictured), the man whose job is to protect front line workers, has a plan for shortages of kit: Never again. He is already planning for a second wave.

item.title: Rowing coach jailed for six years after posing as 16-year-old girl to get 32 teenage boys to undress
item.description: Andrew Cook was convicted of 37 sexual offences involving boys aged between 13 and 17 at London's Hampton School. The teacher posed as a teenage girl, under the name of Anne Jones.

item.title: Love Island Australia cast and villa revealed ahead of its UK launch
item.description: Leading the lineup are a hunky footballer, a naughty nurse, a feisty animal handler and a former beauty queen, all on a mission to find love in the famous Mallorcan villa.

item.title: Thousands of vulnerable pensioners are hit with £125-a-week coronavirus 'tax'
item.description: Vulnerable pensioners in care homes who cover their own fees are being landed with extra 'coronavirus bills', according to research by Age UK.

item.title: Justin Trudeau takes a knee at protest but Twitter immediately calls him out for blackface photos
item.description: Justin Trudeau took a public knee during an anti-racism protest in Ottawa on Friday, but not without being reminded of his blackface photos that emerged last year.

item.title: How BAKING can help you sleep
item.description: Scientists in the UAE say the secret to a good night's rest is having a rewarding hobby. They found those who enjoy relaxing pastimes are more likely to experience better quality sleep.

item.title: 'Quickie' no-fault divorces could be legal from next month
item.description: The reforms will mean a 'no-fault' divorce can be granted to a couple after just six months, rather than the currently enforced separation by agreement after two years.

item.title: Maddie suspect dated a British woman for a year
item.description: German paedophile Christian Brueckner is said to have wooed the British woman by taking her on drives along the Algarve in his classic Jaguar while living in Praia de Luz, Portugal.

item.title: Prince William and Kate Middleton reveal they've been secretly answering helpline phone calls
item.description: The Cambridges revealed they've been answering helpline calls and text messages from their Amner Hall home, during a Zoom call to marked Volunteers' Week on Wednesday.

item.title: World's biggest super-yacht worth £515 million arrives in UK after a week-long voyage from Barcelona
item.description: Dilbar arrived this morning and proved to be a spectacular sight as she made her way up Southampton Water, drawing plenty of admiring glances as she cruised past Hythe.

item.title: Sir Tom Jones reveals he fell for late wife Linda while playing marbles as children
item.description: The age-defying singer trended on Twitter ahead of his milestone 80th birthday as he revealed he fell for his late wife Linda when they played marbles as kids.

item.title: Puppy rescued by Norwegian military after Arctic landslide
item.description: One year old elkhound Raija was on the piece of land that was carried out to sea near the town of Alta, Norway. He was able to swim to land where he was saved by rescuers in a military helicopter.

item.title: People really DO want to be kind to each other even if it costs them something, a new study reveals
item.description: A new study reveals that people really do want to be kind to each other. The team found that individuals choose to be generous to others, even cost themselves and regardless of external motives.

item.title: Fleet of trucks delivers two million pieces of PPE to the NHS in Mail Force's largest delivery yet
item.description: Packed with more than two million pieces of vital personal protective equipment, five 44-ton trucks head in convoy for the front line of the battle against coronavirus.

item.title: Sen Tom Cotton blasts NYT as it caves in over op-ed calling for troops to quash protests
item.description: Sen Tom Cotton of Arkansas questioned backpedaling at the New York Times after it claimed his op-ed was rushed into the editorial process and did not meet the newspaper's standards.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Met sources blast Portuguese police
item.description: Police in Portugal came under fire tonight for their lacklustre response to the biggest potential breakthrough in the abduction of Madeleine McCann since she first disappeared 13 years ago.

item.title: How Madeleine suspect slept in my attic
item.description: This is the dingy attic bolthole where 'nervous' Madeleine suspect Christian Brueckner slept after leaving Portugal 'to start a new life'.

item.title: Mother describes how £195,000 dream home slid into oblivion while she was inside with her family
item.description: Emma Tullett was sitting on the sofa of her home on the Isle of Sheppey in Kent when the roller blind on the window behind her came out of its fitting and clattered to the floor.

item.title: Seen for the first time, the ghostly sight of one Graveyard Gatwick in paralysis
item.description: DAVID JONES: Gatwick has turned from the world's second busiest single-runway airport - its volume of traffic surpassed only by one in Mumbai - into a kind of aviation mausoleum.assembled.

item.title: Care home manager jailed after stealing money from residents
item.description: Helen Hughes, 56, took money from five residents of the Ashton Park Care Home in Newport, South Wales to give to her online lover who conned her into thinking he was an American soldier.

item.title: EDEN CONFIDENTIAL: Camilla mourns one of her best friends Mary Christie who died at 83
item.description: EDEN CONFIDENTIAL: While Prince Charles spoke out this week about how he's missing hugging his grandchildren, his wife is mourning one of her best friends.

item.title: BEL MOONEY: For once in her life, why can't my mum say sorry?
item.description: This week Bel advises a reader who is struggling to understand why her mum can't say sorry.

item.title: Portuguese police insist they passed on Madeleine suspect's name to UK investigators
item.description: Portuguese police chief Carlos Farinha insisted his officers passed on details of German paedophile Christian Brueckner to Scotland Yard in 2012 as part of their Madeleine McCann investigation.

item.title: Woman 'butchered pregnant 17-year-old girl and cut her baby from her womb'
item.description: A woman in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, is being held on murder charges a week after she allegedly killed a teen who was seven months pregnant and cut a baby boy from her womb.

item.title: Meghan Markle sponsors a kennel costing £10-a-month in Archie's name at London dog rescue centre
item.description: The Mayhew shelter in north London asks members of the public to pay £10 a month to sponsor a 'deluxe dog room'. Pictured inset, Megan with Archie, main, during a visit to the shelter.

item.title: 'Russian mercenaries fleeing war-torn Libya' leave teddy bear taped to mortar shell in civilian home
item.description: A cuddly toy was left taped to a mortar shell hidden under a table with a tripwire in a Tripoli home. This comes after the Russian-backed Libyan commander Khalifa Haftar retreated from the capital.

item.title: Post Office could lose power to prosecute staff
item.description: The British Criminal Cases Review Commission has serious concerns after hundreds of postmasters may have been wrongfully convicted for theft, fraud and false accounting.

item.title: Bill Murray's son arrested during Black Lives Matter protest
item.description: Caleb Murray, the son of legendary actor Bill Murray was arrested on Monday in Martha's Vineyard during a Black Lives Matter protest.

item.title: Medieval house where Charles courted Diana and saw Camilla goes on sale for £3.75million
item.description: RICHARD KAY: The medieval house near Chippenham, Wiltshire, is back in the news after a scandal-free 35 year, as it goes up for sale for £3.75million.

item.title: CBI says firms want to get on with leaving the EU even if it means no trade deal
item.description: Dame Carolyn Fairbairn, director-general of the CBI, said the body will not support further delays to the Brexit process. The CBI opposed Brexit and previously voiced support for a longer transition.

item.title: How Boodles was bamboozled by a high-class gang in a £4million Ocean's Eleven-style heist in London
item.description: At society jeweller Boodles, diamonds are a girl's best friend. One such girl arrived at the 200-year-old firm's Bond Street headquarters at 11.09am on the morning of Thursday, March 10, 2016.

item.title: Fortress White House: Tall black fences go up around 1600 Pennsylvania Ave as protests continue
item.description: Tall, black fences have sprung up around the perimeter of the White House as protesters have demonstrated over the death of George Floyd.

item.title: JOHN HUMPHRYS: Clock-watching Britain has lost all track of time
item.description: JOHN HUMPHRYS: For a few terrifying minutes this past week I thought I'd gone mad. Not 'mad' like Jack Nicholson in The Shining. I didn't rush out to the shed with an axe.

item.title: Coronavirus England: Infection figures may be triple ONS data
item.description: Public Health England and Cambridge University estimate that 16,700 people are catching Covid-19 each day, while the Office for National Statistics puts the figure at 5,570 in the community.

item.title: Government advisers warned that PHE's contact tracing capacity would be 'exhausted' in TWO WEEKS
item.description: Papers submitted to the Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE) reveal the evidence government officials were receiving in March and April as the coronavirus gripped the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Fears NW and SW England to stay in lockdown
item.description: Separate estimates produced by experts at Public Health England and Cambridge University today suggested the R rate is above the danger level in both these parts of England.

item.title: GCSE and A-Level pupils face being given WRONG grades
item.description: Pupils risk being handed the wrong GCSE and A-Level grades after concerns were raised over the system used to input results following the cancellation of summer exams due to coronavirus.

item.title: Asteroid travelling at 11,000mph will zip past Earth at a distance of 3.1 million miles tonight
item.description: Despite being nearly 3.1 million miles away - 12 times further out than the Moon - the asteroid is classed as a near Earth object by astronomers and is tracked by NASA.

item.title: Trump's former chief of staff John Kelly stands with Jim Mattis
item.description: John Kelly, the retired general, joined the list of high-profile military officers criticizing the president, suggesting people should at a person's 'character' and 'ethics' before voting for them.

item.title: British captive Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's husband warns time is running out
item.description: British-Iranian Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's husband Richard has blasted the UK Government for not doing more to get her out of a 'hostage situation' in Iran.

item.title: How Boris Johnson's approach to tackling the coronavirus crisis has been hit by blunders and rows
item.description: Boris Johnson is facing growing questions over the UK's response to the coronavirus pandemic with Britain's official death toll now approaching 40,000.

item.title: Did UK's coronavirus crisis peak BEFORE lockdown?
item.description: Modelling by Professor Simon Wood, a mathematician at the University of Bristol, shows the spread of the virus had already peaked several days before the draconian curbs were imposed.

item.title: It's harder to learn about science with modern technology, astrophysicist claims
item.description: Lord Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal, said it was difficult to take a smartphone apart in the same way as dismantling a clock or an engine was in the past.

item.title: The wacky new Tony's Chocolonely mega chocolate factory that has a ROLLER COASTER running through it
item.description: Tony's Chocolonely has released a rendering for its new factory in the Netherlands, which it says will be a 'total experience where you can learn everything about chocolate'.

item.title: Polymer coating for plants could be safer alternative to pesticides
item.description: A new polymer coating developed at the University of Nottingham could serve as a safer alternative to pesticides in controlling harmful fungi that devastates plant crops.

item.title: Father-of-five battered fiancee after she invited her mother to join them on holiday
item.description: Patrick Heaney, from Ardwick, Manchester,, was hoping for an intimate break to Wales with bride-to-be Chloe Pallagi - but was enraged when her mother and other relatives agreed to tag along.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 357 new deaths amid worries of R rate rise
item.description: Department of Health bosses have yet to reveal the breakdown of where the deaths occurred - but NHS England recorded 123 more deaths in patients who tested positive in hospitals.

item.title: Hydroxychloroquine does NOT treat coronavirus, biggest study into the drug finds
item.description: Oxford University scientists pulled the drug from the Recovery trial today after results showed hydroxychloroquine had no benefit on NHS patients hospitalised with the virus.

item.title: Police order evidence review against man suspected of spitting on rail worker who died of Covid-19
item.description: Belly Mujinga died in April aged 47 of coronavirus, a few weeks after the incident at London's Victoria Station. In a new statement, police have invited the CPS to conduct an independent review.

item.title: Adventure travel writer Sadie Whitelocks ventures inside a remote nomadic Mongolian tribe camp
item.description: During an off-roading adventure through Mongolia, Sadie Whitelocks stopped off for tea with a welcoming local family. She was shown how they milk a horse and served snuff in their ger.

item.title: Travellers take over picturesque market town as council bid to evict them is delayed by coronavirus
item.description: A traveller encampment has taken over the picturesque town of Bakewell leaving residents furious. Local council are yet unable to take action, until the full lifting of coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Soldier killed in action lied about age to join D-Day landings
item.description: Jack Banks, from Darwen, Lancashire, who lied about his age to enlist in the British Army, was among the first wave of soldiers to land on Gold Beach as part of Operation Overlord in June 1944.

item.title: Vintage motorbike Colonel Tom Moore used to race on in the 1950s is uncovered at museum
item.description: The timeworn Scott Flying Squirrel is on display at Bradford Industrial Museum in West Yorkshire, but its history wasn't known until a stash of black and white photos were recently discovered.

item.title: Victoria's Secret UK goes into administration putting 800 jobs and 25 stores at risk
item.description: The UK arm of lingerie brand Victoria's Secret has slipped into administration, raising fears for more than 800 employees. Now the 25 stores around the country are now under threat of full closure.

item.title: Care home deaths from any cause rose by 61% during lockdown, data shows
item.description: A report by the Office for National Statistics suggests that undiagnosed Covid-19 is to blame for many of the excess deaths this year, and that elderly people appeared to make up the majority of them.

item.title: Dramatic moment man angrily smashes a tractor window with a BASEBALL BAT in furious row with driver
item.description: An angry man smashes the window of a tractor on a country road in Mayo, Ireland during an argument in this dramatic video in what is believed to have been a dispute over land.

item.title: Father creates huge indoor slide using cardboard boxes on stairs for his children during lockdown
item.description: Parker Wood, from Salem, Utah, created an enormous slide for his children after he was laid off from his job and it has provided hours of entertainment.

item.title: DIY McFly! Back to the Future fanatic takes to skies on a hoverboard using a £340,000 jet pack suit
item.description: Back to the Future fan, Sam Rogers, fulfilled a lifetime ambition as he became the real-life Marty McFly - taking to the skies at a UK-based airfield using a hoverboard and jet suit he created.

item.title: Work resumes on British Normandy Memorial commemorating UK troops who died in the 1944 invasion
item.description: Craftsmen were seen carving the words of Winston Churchill's 'We Shall Fight on the Beaches' speech into the stone walls of the British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer.

item.title: Last month was warmest May on record says EU climate monitor
item.description: Last month was the warmest May on record with global temperatures 1.13°F (0.63°C) above average, according to the European Union's climate change monitor.

item.title: What does YOUR sneeze say about your personality?
item.description: British body language expert Robin Kermode has revealed the meaning behind the different types of sneezes, explaining that a 'loud sneezer is often marking his position as an alpha male'.

item.title: Moment Tommy Robinson 'punches man to the ground' at protest but claims he 'acted in self-defence'
item.description: Tommy Robinson, 37, was detained after police received a report of an assault on a man at Hollywood Retail Park in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, shortly after 8.30pm on Thursday.

item.title: The airlines that will let you book NOW with flexibility for late 2020 and early 2021
item.description: In a bid to help UK passengers-in-waiting book flights with peace of mind, flight tips site Head for Points has read the small print so they don't have to.

item.title: Saxons may never have invaded England after the fall of Roman Britain
item.description: However, one expert believes the 5th century of German-speaking Saxon never really happened. Instead, England slowly evolved based on pre-existing Roman culture.

item.title: Thugs brutally attack man and his pregnant wife during violent carjacking outside their home
item.description: CCTV captured the horrifying moment a pregnant woman and her husband were attacked on their driveway by a gang of thugs who then stole their car in King's Norton, Birmingham.

item.title: Boy's pet lizard tries to catch flies on a game on his phone after mistaking them for real insects
item.description: Luna the lizard, from Kokomo, Indiana, put her bug catching skills to the test when her owner Tyler put his phone inside her tank to keep her entertained.

item.title: 'Odds in favour' of finding other young Earth-like planets in young stellar groups
item.description: Experts from Sheffield studied groups of young stars in the Milky way to determine if they were more likely to harbour so-called 'magma ocean planets' - baby Earths.

item.title: Venice flooded by high tides two days after Italy reopened
item.description: Venice was hit by 4ft tides and heavy rain overnight, leaving parts of the lagoon city including iconic St Mark's Square underwater - just two days after Italy reopened its borders to tourists.

item.title: Vicar, 81, who married Romanian toyboy, 27, dies alone
item.description: An 81-year-old former vicar who married his 27-year-old Romanian toyboy lover has died alone in a Bucharest hospital - as his widow reveals he 'cried for two days' but is now ready to enjoy his inheritance.

item.title: Apple supplier suggests iPhone 12 will be delayed at least a month
item.description: A supplier to Apple has revealed that the tech giant's upcoming iPhone will be delayed from its usual September launch, due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Pregnant woman gives partner second chance after he fractured her eye socket in savage attack
item.description: Peter Dougal, 32, was arrested after he grabbed Joanne Hough and repeatedly punched her in the face after he became drunk and argumentative during a night out in Lees, Greater Manchester.

item.title: AstraZeneca ALREADY manufacturing Covid vaccine in three countries
item.description: AstraZeneca's chief executive, Pascal Soriot, said the firm has started to mass-produce the AZD1222 jab, developed by Oxford University, at factories in India, the UK, Switzerland and Norway.

item.title: Submerged Italian town could be about to re-emerge from lake
item.description: Fabbriche di Careggine, a former village in Tuscany which now sits beneath the waters of Lake Vagli, could reemerge when the waters are drained to carry out repairs on a dam - with people allowed to visit.

item.title: Masks should be compulsory in shops, restaurants and pubs, says BMA
item.description: Commuters again packed on to the London Underground and were forced to break social distancing rules on the Jubilee Line, which runs through the heart of the capital.

item.title: Meghan Markle sounded 'less restrained' and 'like her old self' in George Floyd speech
item.description: Speaking to Vanity Fair today, a friend said the duchess sounded 'less restrained' and more like she did before she joined the royal family in her speech about George Floyd's death.

item.title: British Airways boycotts summit with Priti Patel amid furious row
item.description: Chief Executive of IAG Willie Walsh (pictured) said there had been no consultation with the UK airline industry prior to the rule change and he was reviewing possible action with lawyers.

item.title: Robbers disguised as health inspectors steal £10,000 from South African supermarket
item.description: The armed gang are believed to have made off with 200,000 ZAR, £9,392, from a pension payout point at a supermarket in Pietermaritzburg in KwaZulu-Natal province on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Nottinghamshire Police officers rugby tackle fleeing drug dealer after high-speed car chase
item.description: Timothy Glover, 32, was rugby tackled to the ground after a nine-minute police chase during which he jumped red lights and drove the wrong way around bollards in Bulwell, Nottinghamshire.

item.title: Lion whose eye was gouged out in a brutal battle resembles villain in Disney's Lion King
item.description: 'One Eye' was captured on camera in Khwai, Botswana. The lion was left with a gaping wound over his right eye making him bare a striking resemblance to the villain in Disney's Lion King.

item.title: Drunk ex-nurse drowned in ditch after going for a cigarette while celebrating her 54th birthday
item.description: A former nurse drowned in a drainage ditch behind a marquee at a cider farm near Highbridge, Somerset while celebrating her birthday at a traditional drinking event, an inquest heard.

item.title: Nine News reporter is nearly attacked by crocodile while filming segment in Darwin
item.description: Reporter Zarisha Bradley was filming a segment in Darwin on Thursday when she decided to take a closer look at the beast lurking in the water below.

item.title: Toddler with Down Syndrome can't hide his delight as he meets his newborn baby brother
item.description: This is the adorable moment a boy with Down syndrome meets his baby brother for the first time and can't stop smiling about it - and even gives him a little kiss on his forehead.

item.title: Australian pet owner returns home to find his dog has ripped his new £2,800 sofa to shreds
item.description: Jaccob Mckay, 26, was shocked to come home and see sofa stuffing all over his living room in Olinda near Melbourne, Australia. He believes 10-month-old Cypress was protesting being left alone.
